title: 3rd century BC
text:
The 3rd century BC started the first day of <a href="300%20BC">300 BC</a> and ended the last day of <a href="201%20BC">201 BC</a>. It is considered part of the Classical <a href="era">era</a>, <a href="Epoch%20%28reference%20date%29">epoch</a>, or <a href="historical%20period">historical period</a>.
In the <a href="Mediterranean%20Basin">Mediterranean Basin</a>, the first few decades of this century were characterized by a balance of power between the <a href="Greeks">Greek</a> <a href="Hellenistic">Hellenistic</a> kingdoms in the east, and the great mercantile power of <a href="Carthage">Carthage</a> in the west. This balance was shattered when conflict arose between <a href="ancient%20Carthage">ancient Carthage</a> and the <a href="Roman%20Republic">Roman Republic</a>. In the following decades, the <a href="Carthaginian%20Republic">Carthaginian Republic</a> was first humbled and then destroyed by the Romans in the <a href="First%20Punic%20War">First</a> and Second <a href="Punic%20Wars">Punic Wars</a>. Following the <a href="Second%20Punic%20War">Second Punic War</a>, Rome became the most important power in the western Mediterranean.
In the <a href="eastern%20Mediterranean">eastern Mediterranean</a>, the <a href="Seleucid%20Empire">Seleucid Empire</a> and <a href="Ptolemaic%20Kingdom">Ptolemaic Kingdom</a>, <a href="Diadochi">successor states</a> to the empire of <a href="Alexander%20the%20Great">Alexander the Great</a>, fought a series of <a href="Syrian%20Wars">Syrian Wars</a> for control over the <a href="Levant">Levant</a>. In <a href="mainland%20Greece">mainland Greece</a>, the short-lived <a href="Antipatrid%20dynasty">Antipatrid dynasty</a> of <a href="Macedon">Macedon</a> was overthrown and replaced by the <a href="Antigonid%20dynasty">Antigonid dynasty</a> in 294 BC, a royal house that would dominate the affairs of <a href="Hellenistic%20Greece">Hellenistic Greece</a> for roughly a century until the stalemate of the <a href="First%20Macedonian%20War">First Macedonian War</a> against <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Rome</a>. Macedon would also lose the <a href="Cretan%20War%20%28205%E2%80%93200%20BC%29">Cretan War</a> against the Greek city-state of <a href="Rhodes">Rhodes</a> and its allies.
In <a href="India">India</a>, <a href="Ashoka">Ashoka</a> ruled the <a href="Maurya%20Empire">Maurya Empire</a>. The <a href="Early%20Pandyan%20Kingdom">Pandya</a>, <a href="early%20Cholas">Chola</a> and <a href="Chera%20Dynasty">Chera</a> dynasties of the classical age flourished in the <a href="ancient%20Tamil%20country">ancient Tamil country</a>.
The <a href="Warring%20States">Warring States</a> period in <a href="Imperial%20China">China</a> drew to a close, with <a href="Qin%20Shi%20Huang">Qin Shi Huang</a> conquering the six other nation-states and establishing the short-lived <a href="Qin%20dynasty">Qin dynasty</a>, the first empire of China, which was followed in the same century by the long-lasting <a href="Han%20dynasty">Han dynasty</a>. However, a brief interregnum and civil war existed between the Qin and Han periods known as the <a href="Chu-Han%20contention">Chu-Han contention</a>, lasting until 202 BC with the ultimate victory of <a href="Liu%20Bang">Liu Bang</a> over <a href="Xiang%20Yu">Xiang Yu</a>.
The <a href="Proto%E2%80%93Three%20Kingdoms%20Period">Protohistoric Period</a> began in <a href="Korean%20Peninsula">Korea</a>. In the following century the Chinese Han dynasty would conquer the <a href="Gojoseon">Gojoseon</a> kingdom of northern Korea. The <a href="Xiongnu">Xiongnu</a> were at the height of their power in <a href="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>. They defeated the Han Chinese at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Baideng">Battle of Baideng</a> in 200 BC, marking the beginning of the forced "<a href="Heqin">Heqin</a>" tributary agreement and marriage alliance that would last several decades.
